w:r.w:t: MindM8 is an AI-assisted emotional clarity app. It helps people think more clearly about their emotions and relationships through guided reflection sessions, daily check-ins, and pattern recognition.

It is not therapy. It is not a chatbot. It is a structured space where someone can arrive carrying something — an unnamed feeling, a difficult conversation, a sense of being overwhelmed — and leave having seen it more clearly.
as a progressive web app (PWA). All data stays on the user’s device. There is no backend database, no account creation, and no personal data ever leaves the browser.

MindM8 is framed as a space people arrive at — not a tool they use. Each session mode is designed around arrival language: Arrive Clearer (reflection), Arrive Ready (conversation preparation), Arrive Present (grounding). After a session, the user should feel they have moved — even slightly — toward clarity, readiness, or presence.

MindM8 never gives advice. It asks questions. The insight comes from the user, not from the AI. The voice is warm but grounded — a thoughtful friend who listens well, not a clinical stranger reading from a script.

Every piece of data — sessions, themes, check-ins, letters, settings — lives in localStorage on the user’s device. There is no server-side storage, no user accounts, and no way for anyone (including us) to access a user’s reflections. The only server calls are to the Claude API during active sessions, and those conversations are not retained by Anthropic.

A dedicated safety layer overrides all other instructions. If a user expresses suicidal intent, self-harm plans, or escalating threats, MindM8 immediately redirects to crisis resources (Samaritans 116 123, 988 Lifeline, findahelpline.com). It never attempts to counsel through a crisis, never asks clinical assessment questions, and never locks the user out.
MindM8 offers four distinct session modes, each designed for a specific emotional need.
Guided reflection. 5 exchanges. Helps the user process an emotion, an event, or something they can’t name yet. Open, exploratory questions that help them see patterns and set things down.

Conversation preparation. 7 exchanges. Helps the user clarify what they want to say before a difficult real-world conversation. Structured, goal-oriented questions. Includes optional letter writing and before/after follow-ups.
Grounding. 3 exchanges. For moments of overwhelm. Minimal and containing — name one feeling, sit with it, close warmly.
Breathing and grounding. 2 minutes. No AI, no questions. Just guided breathing with visual pacing. For moments when you need to be present without processing.

Each session begins with an intro screen showing the mode heading, a description of what to expect, and a tip. A breathing meditation circle provides a visual anchor. Sessions end with a Readiness Moment and optional takeaway.
One-word mood check-in. “How are you arriving today?” Tracks the last 7 days and detects patterns (e.g. “3 of your last 7 check-ins were anxious”).
After check-in, surfaces related themes from past reflections. “Last time, it was connected to: feeling unseen at work.” Offers a “Sit with this?” gateway to a reflect session.

MindM8 uses a 5-layer prompt system where each layer has clear ownership and can be updated independently:
Core identity, arrival framing, voice rules, acknowledgment guidelines. Defines what MindM8 is and is not.
Crisis detection and response protocol. Overrides all other layers. Handles self-harm, suicidal intent, and escalating threats.
Mode-specific instructions (Reflect/Prepare/Ground), exchange counter, closing reflection trigger at final exchange.
Injects abstracted patterns from previous reflections. Enables gentle connections without quoting the user directly.
User’s self-provided “About You” text. Shapes questions naturally without reading back what they shared.
Sends conversation to Claude with all prompt layers. Returns AI response (max 500 tokens). Auto-detects session completion.
Analyses full session transcript after completion. Extracts primary emotion, behavioural theme, and relationship context. Flags crisis-adjacent content.
Receives user feedback from Settings. Logged to Vercel function logs for review.

Aggregated from the post-session Readiness Moment. Shows distribution of Yes / A little / Not yet responses over the last 14 days with an interpretive summary.

MindM8’s current architecture is designed for individual privacy: static frontend, localStorage persistence, no accounts, no backend database. This is the right design for building trust with early users. But organisational licensing requires a different model — one that preserves privacy where it matters while adding the visibility that commissioners and partners need.

The content of reflections — what people actually say in sessions — never leaves the device. Session transcripts, themes, takeaways, letters, check-in entries, PIN data, and recovery words remain in localStorage. This is the core privacy promise and it does not change under licensing. No organisation, commissioner, or administrator can read a user’s reflections.

Anonymous usage telemetry: session started, session completed, mode used, readiness response, timestamp, and an organisation identifier. No personal content, no names, no reflection text — just event counts. This gives licensing partners three things they need: billing data (monthly active users per organisation), usage analytics (how many people are using the tool and how often), and aggregate outcome signals (readiness trends across a population, completion rates, mode preferences).

The intended model is per-organisation licensing based on user bands. An NHS Trust or charity partner pays a monthly fee based on agreed active user tiers (e.g. up to 500 users, up to 2,000 users, up to 5,000 users). The organisation receives a usage dashboard showing anonymous aggregate data: total sessions, completion rates, mode distribution, readiness trends, and monthly active users. API costs (Anthropic Claude) are absorbed into the license fee as an operational expense.

Moving to organisational licensing requires a lightweight server-side layer. This includes: an anonymous event ingestion endpoint that receives usage events (no personal content) and stores them in a managed database; an organisation dashboard for commissioners to view aggregate usage and outcomes; organisation-scoped access via invite codes or domain-based routing so users are associated with a licensing partner without creating accounts; and rate limiting per organisation to manage API costs against license tiers.

Critically, the user-facing experience remains unchanged. Sessions still run client-side. Reflections still stay on the device. The server-side layer handles only operational and billing data — the kind of anonymised metrics that GDPR allows without explicit consent under legitimate interest, provided no personal data is processed.

MindM8’s questioning techniques are informed by cognitive behavioural principles: thought challenging (“Has there been a time when that wasn’t true?”), pattern recognition (“You’ve noticed this before”), reframing (offering a different angle on the same situation), and behavioural nudges (“Is there one small thing you could try before next time?”). These are embedded in the conversation naturally, not presented as clinical tools.

This is a deliberate positioning choice. MindM8 is “CBT-informed, not CBT-claiming.” It uses evidence-based questioning frameworks without making clinical claims, which keeps it outside MHRA medical device classification while still aligning with NHS Talking Therapies language and evidence standards. For NHS partners, this positions MindM8 as a complement to commissioned services — particularly as a “waiting well” tool for people on therapy waitlists, or a between-session bridging tool for people already in treatment.

MindM8 occupies a unique space in the emotional wellness market. It is not a therapy app (Woebot, Wysa), not a journaling app (Day One, Reflectly), not a meditation app (Calm, Headspace), and not a companion chatbot (Replika, Character.ai).

MindM8 is a readiness engine. It helps people arrive clearer at their own thoughts, readier for their own conversations, and more present in their own lives. The closest analogy is a thoughtful friend who listens well and asks the right question at the right time.
Relationship-aware: reflections are tagged to specific relationships and tracked over time
Privacy-first by architecture: no accounts, no cloud storage, no data leaves the device
Structured sessions with clear endings: not an endless chatbot loop
Pattern recognition: AI extracts emotional themes across sessions, surfacing what the user might not see themselves
Safety-conscious: crisis detection with immediate redirect, no clinical language, no emotional dependency
